title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include business facilitation visitors, defined as aliens visiting the US temporarily for business purposes such as providing services or receiving training. Business facilitation visitors must receive management or technical training from personnel of a United States entity. Additionally, no alien may be admitted as a business facilitation visitor unless their country has arrangements with the US to combat visa fraud using measures like machine-readable passports and biometric technology. The conditions for business facilitation visitors include the use of machine-readable passports and biometric technology, as determined by the consular officer based on evidence provided by the alien. Remuneration and expenses related to the provision of services must also be met. The alien's employer must pay all remuneration and expenses for services provided, and the alien must be qualified with expert knowledge and necessary licenses to work in the United States. The alien must be an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity for management or technical training. The alien must be affiliated with a US entity for management or technical training, with all expenses covered by the employer. The alien must have at least 5 years of management experience, detailed knowledge of the employer's business operations, and hold a management level position within the employer within 1 year of completing the training. The alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services can stay for up to 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension in case of unforeseen delays in completing the services described in the contract. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training may not exceed 1 year. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission as business facilitation visitors if they engage in fraud. The Secretary of Homeland Security can restrict nationals from entering as business facilitation visitors if they commit fraud. A qualifying services contract is defined as a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a US entity, outlining the time period, duties, and payment provisions for the alien. The qualifying services contract between a foreign provider and a US entity must ensure that the alien receives fair working conditions, possesses necessary credentials, and outlines the responsibilities of the foreign provider. The qualifying services contract between a foreign provider and a US entity must ensure fair working conditions for the alien, their compliance with admission terms, and their return to their home country at the end of their admission period.
